PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the READER

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked will have exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to exactly the same experiences as others. It is impossible for you to answer all of them, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces where they don't apply.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1945, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write their answers separately.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives has prepared a questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Tales: What Did Saskatchewan Pioneers Eat?" It is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here.

Saskatchewan Archives has prepared questionnaires on other subjects which you would be willing to answer:

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? 

On the family all came together. Some of us were too young to attend. All children all came well at the same time. She traveled by train.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? 

We traveled by ourselves.

13. What means of transportation did you use? 

On the C.P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, etc.)

The journey had no very exciting incidents as the train was slow and we were all day in Winnipeg on Easter Sunday in 1876, and remembered all of all being crowded together and sleeping on the floor in a floored compartment. After we reached our destination we became anxious about the future and worried about the circumstances of having a wife and children.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed in a small town called Whitelaw.

16. How did you settle or take up land?

We settled on the homestead.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Moved from N.B. to Wabamun, Alta. in 1916, then moved from Strathcona to Prince in 1918.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My living was fairly well supplied on the farm until I could purchase up until 1899 when school teaching came into the picture, and after January 1900 as a farmer's wife.
11. What did your parents and relatives think or say about coming to Canada?

On the family all came together, some of us were too young to attend school.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

We traveled by train.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

The train.

14. What memories of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, etc.)

The journey had many exciting incidents. We were all day in Greenup on Easter Sunday in 1886, and remembered well of all being excited together and cheering on the train in all places.

15. What did you first see when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I saw the prairie and the trees.

16. How did you feel when you arrived?

I felt very happy.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Moved from Prince Albert to Regina in 1918.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

My husband was fairly well supplied with the land he could purchase up until 1918 when we started teaching our children and after January 1900 as a farmer's wife.

19. How old were you when you came to Canada?

I was 18 years old.

20. What was your occupation before coming to Canada?

I was a housewife.

21. What was your occupation after coming to Canada?

I became a homemaker.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

On the family all came together, some of us were too young to think of relations.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

An entire family and 4 children all came West at the same time.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By the C.P.R.

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement)

The journey was very exciting incident.

As the trails they did not know on Monday we were all day in sunshine on Easter Sunday in 1886 and remember well of all being crowded together and sleeping on the floor in a large homestead shed. When we reached our destination and friendly greeted, there was always a hand wash, wash and marking and smiling, the circumstances of our homes were always a delight.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

When we arrived in Assiniboia, we had our first meal was in a private home in the back end of Wolseley.

This house was built by Mr. and Mrs. Wolseley.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

S.E. of Wolseley

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Moved from N.S. to Wolseley Area in 1886, then moved from Wolseley to Prince in 1898.

That was the only move the writer ever made.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My living was pretty well supplied in those early years, to gather with the bit of help the writer could furnish up until 1898 when school teaching came into the picture and after January 1900 as a farmers wife.

We arrived in Assiniboia on April 7th and stayed in a private home in the back end of a house for a short time before moving into a house near the railroad.

16. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Minnedifton, N.W.T., Waskesiu, Assiniboia, and finally Saskatoon.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Many and varied were the experiences of those early days...hailed hail, dried hail, frozen hail, but the never-to-be-forgotten were the prairie fires. By day the air was filled with smoke and the fire burned the wool, and when night would come, the fire would be seen miles and miles away. Our fires were mostly South West, the direction of the wind. Sometimes where the fires very often originated, there was nothing to stop them but the C.P.R., which they did not burn.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Some moved away to try and make a living elsewhere as the crops were not good and the buffalos bones were getting harder to collect. Still bones furnished the ready cash supply.

Skaggs Town was named after the first settlers who took up land there about six miles north of Reese.

There were six Skaggs brothers all homes located near the townsite, the land for the town being bought from Adam Skaggs. The first elevator was built in June 1911 and about then the railroad was put through. The old homestead of the father was sold through. He died at the age of 36. His sons were known far and wide as "Skaggs."

He died at Marshalltown, Iowa when he was seventy-five years old.
